speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me exactly when you first noticed the swelling and pain in your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about 2 days ago, during a football game. I was playing and my finger got caught in another player's jersey, and he pulled it really hard.

speaker: Doctor
text: About two weeks ago, I woke up and my finger was swollen and sore. It's been getting progressively worse since then.

speaker: Patient
text: No, it wasn't like that for me. It happened all at once, right in that moment when I got caught. It's been getting worse ever since, but it's not been a gradual thing.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any trauma or injury to the finger prior to noticing the swelling and pain?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I've already told you - it happened during a football game when my finger got caught in another player's jersey and he pulled it really hard.

speaker: Doctor
text:
No, I haven't experienced any trauma or injury to the finger prior to noticing the swelling and pain. I did have a bit of a pinching incident with a door a few months ago, but that was on my left hand, not my right.

Can you tell me if the pain is constant or does it come and go throughout the day?

speaker: Patient
text: It's constant, it doesn't really go away. It's just there all the time, even when I'm not doing anything with my hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain does come and go, but it's been getting worse over time. It's more constant at night when I'm trying to sleep. Can you describe the sensation of the pain - is it a sharp, stabbing pain, or more of a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more of a dull ache, but it can get sharp when I try to move my finger. It feels like it's throbbing.

speaker: Doctor
text:
The pain is a bit of a dull ache, but sometimes it can feel a little sharp, especially when I move my finger. 

Have you noticed any redness or discoloration around the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, there's a bit of redness and swelling around my right ring finger. It's more noticeable when I look at it, but it's not like it's a huge red spot or anything.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your fingernail or the skin around the affected area, such as thickening or a change in color?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I haven't really noticed anything out of the ordinary with my fingernail. It looks pretty normal to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in your right ring finger, or in your hand in general?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in my finger or hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your ability to move your finger or perform activities that require dexterity, such as playing musical instruments or typing?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I have noticed that it's harder for me to move my finger, especially when I'm trying to make a fist. It feels like it's stiff and I have to really force it to bend.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms. Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently, or have you experienced any fever or chills?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any changes in my appetite or weight. I've been eating normally and feeling pretty healthy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you traveled or been exposed to anyone who has been traveling recently, or have you been in contact with anyone who has been sick?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't traveled anywhere recently and I haven't been in contact with anyone who's been sick. I've been pretty busy with school and sports, so I don't really have a lot of time to socialize outside of that.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your recent travel and exposure history. Have you had any vaccinations or preventive measures in place, such as antibiotics or antiviral medications, during your recent travel or exposure?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any vaccinations or preventive measures recently. I'm pretty up to date on all my shots, though.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any lumps or nodules under the skin of your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text:
Actually, when I try to make a fist, my finger feels like it's stuck and it doesn't move as easily as my other fingers do. 

There's a bit of a bump on the tip of my finger, but I'm not really sure if that's related to what's going on or not.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any difficulty walking or bearing weight on your hand due to the pain or swelling in your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any trouble walking or bearing weight on my hand. The pain and swelling are mostly limited to my right ring finger.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your right ring finger more closely. Can you please extend your hand and show me the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: It's extended right now, like it always is when I'm not using my hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm going to gently press on the swollen area to assess any tenderness. Can you tell me if you've experienced any tingling or numbness in your finger when I apply pressure?

speaker: Patient
text: No, it doesn't feel like it's numb or tingling, even when you press on it. It just feels sore and tender.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the tenderness when I apply pressure. Now, I'd like to check the range of motion in your right ring finger. Can you please make a fist with your hand and then extend your finger to its full length?

speaker: Patient
text: I can try to make a fist, but it's a bit harder to move my finger than it is with my other fingers. When I try to flex my finger, it feels like it's stuck and it doesn't want to move.

speaker: Doctor
text: Your finger seems to be moving freely, but I do notice a slight restriction when you extend it fully. Can you tell me if you've had any recent exposure to chemicals or toxins at work or in your daily activities?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I'm just a student and I don't really work with any chemicals or toxins.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you don't seem to be showing any visible signs of infection, such as redness or pus, which is a good sign. However, the progressive nature of your symptoms is concerning. Have you had any recent blood tests or screenings that might be relevant to your condition?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any recent blood tests or screenings. I'm not really sure why I would need to, since I'm feeling pretty healthy overall.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of your symptoms and examination results. I must admit, I'm a bit concerned about the possibility of cancer, given the recent diagnosis of a doctor with similar symptoms. 

However, I'm going to take a step back and review all the information we've gathered. Can you tell me, have you ever experienced any similar symptoms or conditions in the past, such as arthritis or a previous injury to the finger?

DIAGNOSIS_READY_Answer: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
